basics.name: Chris Game
basics.label: Programmer
basics.summary: I am a passionate developer always seeking to improve my knowledge and technical understanding. I have been a developer all of my working life and have learnt many skills from being in the industry as long as i have. I have a good understanding of the full stack, but for me this is not just a technical statement but extends from an idea all the way through to support and performance tuning. Having been in this feedback loop for a good few years now i have learned a few lessons. I care deeply about the work i produce and spend a lot of my own time trying to better myself. Currently focussing most of my energy on ember and whats left on d3.

work.summary: My current role has allowed me to explore the benefits of various automation techniques and tools to improve the productivity and ownership of the team. Over the years i have been here I have found a good set of tools in github, circle ci, browserstack and heroku that have allowed myself and the rest of the team to develop a reputation within the company for cost effective high quality solutions. This also meant i was rewarded the control to hire and shape the team as time went on. When i first started i was responsible for one java app but now that has become a suite of apps written in ruby and javascript. More specifically rails, rails-api, sinatra, sails, express, koa and ember using data storage such as postgres, S3, redis and mongo
highlights: I introduced ruby to the team and always trying to find the right tool for the job led us on to build 100% javascript apps
I pushed my ruby knowledge to a level where i was able to mentor others with no ruby knowledge to proficient developers whilst delivering a product to a deadline
I was able to convince the department heads that the developers could and should be responsible for testing their own code (a big deal in this environment!)
I built a strong enough case to be allowed to deploy applications using heroku rather than the internal infrastructure
I built a continuous deployment build chain that included a step that captured screenshots of pages to check for styling regressions
I helped push the adoption of github across the department
I'm also completly happy to follow someone else's lead when they are using good tech ;-)

work.summary: This was my first experience of working in an agile/XP environment. It was a vast improvement over the ways of working i had experienced up to this point. The feedback loop was much faster and i instantly felt i was learning at a much faster rate. This was also due to pairing, a skill i did not posses before this role, i found the experience very rewarding. I learnt a lot technically but also learnt how different peoples thought processes and ways of working vary. I use what i learnt during this time on a day to day basis. This was predominately a Java environment but ruby was used for testing and towards the end of my time in this role we were writing some of the apps in ruby
highlights: Progressing from being the one of the first junior developers the team hired to being a valued senior developer
Performing the role of scrum master for six months

work.summary: Worked as a Analyst Programmer on various projects from content management to provisioning systems. The technologies here were java and C++
highlights: Actually getting to write some code! There was a lot of spec writing and architectural designing required before you were allowed to start coding

work.summary: DA Systems provide IT solutions for the transport & logistics industry throughout the UK. This was a great job to have after uni. I went straight in to a small team developing a new product. I was using Delphi here
highlights: Writing an interface gateway to allow a number of mobile devices to feed data into the app

work.summary: Aspley produce E-Fit a facial identification application that is sold mainly to the security services. My responsibilities ranged from technical support to implementing updates to the application.

publications.name: Agile Horizons 2013
publications.summary: Spoke at a conference sky hosted for about 200 people that included their own staff and guests from other areas of the industry including the BBC
